Note by the President of the Board of Trade.I think my colleagues will be interested to see the following Resolution which has been sent to me by the Seafarers' Joint Council."That this Seafarers' Joint Council after hearing the reportof the Deputation and particularly the statement of the Presidentof the Board of Trade, that the Treaty Is urgently necessary tobring the overseas trade of this country back to normal, get theships which are now laid up underway and considerably reduce un-employment, are of the opinion that no useful purpose will be served in the interests of the men of the sea by opposing theGovernment in their efforts to negotiate the Treaty".The Seafarers1 Joint Council is composed of the following unions and associationsImperial Merchant Service Guild. Mercantile Marine Service Association. Marine Engineers' Association.Association of Wireless and Cable Telegraphists. National Sailors' and Firemen1s Union. United Kingdom Pilots' Association. Ship Constructors' and Shipwrights' Association. Boiler,Makers'and Iron and Steel Shipbuilders' Association. United Operative Plumbers & Domestic Engineers' Association.It comprises therefore practically the whole of the MercantileMarine with the negligible exception of Mr. Shinwell's moribundunion.I think I can say with confidence that if the opposition of the Masters had been less vehement the resolution would have taken an even stronger form, as Mr. Havelock-Wilson's union, which representsseoret.CP. 9 (25). the great majority of the rank and file of the service, has most loyally implemented the undertaking which Mr. Havelock-Wilson gave to me privately/In these circumstances I hope we shall be able to pass the Treaty Bill without any substantial opposition.(Intd). P. C-L.Board of Trade,5th January, 1925.
